alert.note: Alert for Southeast Suffolk; Southern Nassau; Southwest Suffolk (New York) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS New York City - Upton (Long Island and New York City)
info.headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 15 at 4:19PM EDT until September 17 at 3:00AM EDT by NWS New York City - Upton
info.description: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT SATURDAY... ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM EDT SUNDAY... * WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to 16 feet on into Saturday morning in the surf zone, then gradually subsiding through the weekend. For the High Rip Current Risk, dangerous rip currents. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, a reasonable worst case of 1 to 2 ft of inundation above ground level in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. * WHERE...Southwest Suffolk, Southeast Suffolk and Southern Nassau Counties. * WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Saturday. For the High Rip Current Risk, through Saturday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 6 PM Friday to 3 AM EDT Sunday, particularly during the times of high tides. * COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Minor flooding in the most vulnerable locations near the waterfront and shoreline, particularly along the north facing shorelines of the south fork of Long Island and the north facing shorelines of the barrier islands. As much as 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible, which will cause shallow flooding on some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses with basements near the waterfront. * SWIMMING IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions Tonight through Saturday. Life-threatening rip currents are likely for all people entering the surf zone. Anyone visiting the beaches should stay out of the surf. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. * BEACH EROSION AND FLOODING IMPACTS...Large breaking waves will result in widespread areas of dune erosion and scattered overwashes through Saturday high tides. This may result in scattered areas of minor to moderate flooding of roadways and vulnerable structures behind protective dunes. * FORECAST CHALLENGES...There is still uncertainty in the timing of peak surge relative to the times of high tide Tonight into Saturday, the magnitude of wave setup effects over several tidal cycles, and the fact that Lee is expected to transition to an extra- tropical storm. For this reason, this coastal flood forecast represents a reasonable worst case forecast, to include a safety margin for preparation. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Inexperienced swimmers should remain out of the water due to dangerous surf conditions. If you enter the surf zone, always have a flotation device with you and swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and float, and do not swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and yell or wave for help.

area.areaDesc: Southeast Suffolk; Southern Nassau; Southwest Suffolk
